question: What?! * June, mouthing "There's some guy over there wants to see you." Then she gestures to a Continental Town Car in the parking lot next to The House of Bliss.
answer: Mr. Bliss, I'd like to have word with you, if I may.

question: You're talking to the wrong godammed party, you know that?
answer: I think it's in your best interest to hear me out.

question: No, you hear me out, friend... He takes note of the driver coming around the front of the car. He stops a few feet off and unbuttons his jacket, revealing the cross-strap of a shoulder holster. Look, I happen to have a very high regard for this party. And maybe I even have some feelings of a personal nature here.
answer: Well I don't want to appear to be taking unfair advantage of you...

question: Goddamned right.
answer: But in developing certain information on you, it's come to our attention that your name isn't Harry Bliss. That in fact, your name is Eugene Earl Axline... *

question: Wait a minute.
answer: And that both the I.R.S., and an impressive number of creditors in several Eastern cities... ... seem to be somewhat interested in your whereabouts. Harry stands up, leaving the vulnerable area of his stomach framed in the passenger window. When he leans back down, a deeply conflicted expression is apparent on his face:

question: You know, that's not necessarily entirely accurate, I mean, I don't know where you come up with these so-called facts, but... I can't go sneaking around, stealing this lady's property.
answer: I'd like to pose that the name and reputation of this very decent man, is not the property of Mrs. Ellerman, or her sister. * He takes a voucher from the folder and sets the file aside: And it's my hope that we can avoid any unpleasant eventualities, either for you, or for someone you have such admirable feelings toward...

question: What do you mean, 'unpleasant'?
answer: I mean that Mr. Layls is prepared to do whatever it takes to confiscate this document. And if you'd like to be of some assistance * to us, by finding it and turning * it over to me, he'd like to offer * you this very generous gift. * He holds the voucher out to Harry who avoids looking at it:

question: Oh, Socorro... Could you come in here, por favor? As Socorro comes to the landing, Joan indicates one of the open desk drawers: I-am-looking-for-my-sister's-book. Socorro steps closer and glancing into the the now disorderly contents of the drawer, shakes her head defensively:
answer: No. No es mi.

question: La manuscripto ... de mi hermana, Andy, si? I go... toda la casa... Everywhere... Looking y looking... And no es anywhere. Sabe usted?
answer: No se, no entiendo... Lo siento...

question: I told this detective I wanted to press charges against Red Layls, for abducting Andy, for burglarizing my apartment, for breaking into her house...
answer: Oh come on, you're way off.

question: And that he's been trying to scare and intimidate me in case I might have read something in her manuscript that he doesn't want anybody to know. And you know what he said? That I haven't given him probable cause to even go and question Red Layls, or his lawyer...
answer: Well, he's right, I could've told you that. This is a man who goes fishing with the President, honey. He's a little high up to go around burglarizing people and sending them nasty notes. So why don't you just ease back on this thing for awhile... Life's too godammed short.

question: I can't do that, Harry. This is my sister. I can at least make out a missing persons report on her, and then I want to talk to the private detective friend of yours.
answer: I'm trying to chase the guy down, okay? But don't go and make yourself sick... He begins pushing the paraphernalia around on his desk: I mean, Jesus, why don't you just get this damn thing and hand it over to me and I'll give it to these guys.

question: You mean to Red?
answer: Yeah, to Red, or whoever...

question: Well if I ever find, it, that's the last thing I'd do with it.
answer: Dammit, you're making my work more difficult for me, you know that!

question: What is this, have I come at the wrong time or something?
answer: I tell you what the hell to do and you don't listen to me! Joan looks down at the floor, attempting a drollery:

question: Well, someone abates your maidenhood and suddenly feels they can start ordering you around.
answer: I'm not ordering you around. I'm just giving you my opinion. And maybe I get tired of hearing about this stuff all the time, this book business, this manu-whatever, and Red Layls, and your sister.

question: Oh. Well... I'm sorry if I've overtaxed you with my problems, Harry, but I never asked you to consider them a part of your work. So why don't we speak when you're in a better frame of mind. As she crosss to the door, Harry stands up:
answer: Ah honey, now...

question: What's her problem. Now what's she complaining about? ... I come over here to look at the ball game and you give me these clowns. A COMMERCIAL comes on. June hands him the remote and he sits down on the couch, channeling to a BASEBALL GAME: I mean, what's wrong with these women.
answer: You want a know something?

question: They don't want to hear the truth, that's what disturbs me.
answer: There's some people that don't treat me like you do.

question: You tell them the truth and they come at you with a cleaver.
answer: I know one guy that says very complimentary things to me, like that I have nice features and a sense of humor. *

question: What guy?
answer: Some guy I met, that likes me. He looks at her, then reaches over and places a hand affectionately on the nape of her neck:

question: You're going to leave me, lard, just after I've broken you in, and taught you the fine art of dog training?
answer: Maybe. * As if you cared. *

question: Why didn't you have the damn dog with you, that's what he's for!
answer: I told you, he was in the house.

question: What the hell good is that! You have to have him with you at all times!
answer: No you didn't, I said he was dangerous, and you said he wasn't...

question: Yeah, but that's before he tried to part your hair with an axe!
answer: I don't know if it was him. Maybe it was this tree surgeon... She starts to move toward the bedroom and he stops her:

question: It's not more than one person. I'm telling you who the hell it is!
answer: But I don't think Red would have someone sing into my answering machine... It doesn't seem like something he'd do.

question: Dammit, Joan!! She steps out of the closet and comes toward the bedroom, * dressed in one of Andy's negligees.
answer: God, what is this?! I can't say anything to you anymore, you're so darn touchy!

question: You can mention anything you want, * honey. I'm just trying to keep you from turning up face down, that's all. After a moment
answer: It's Andy's --

question: It's very becoming on you.
answer: -- Maybe I don't quite fill it out.

question: Yes you do.
answer: Well? What are you going to do now? Are you going to leave?

question: Yeah, I'm going to skip down the hill, take care of a few things, pick up some clothes...
answer: Could you be back for dinner, around 7:00?

question: Yeah. Sure.
answer: Good. She waves to him and pulls the rest of the way out of the garage, revealing the ax handle still embedded in the front of the car, its handle sharply angled up from the hood like a soup ladle.

question: Hi.
answer: Ella no esta aqui.

question: I just want to look for my... ... watch, I think I left it... ... in there.
answer: Ah si, es okay.

question: Harry! What the hell do you think you're doing?
answer: I just got a phone call, honey, from a prominent entertainer up in Vegas, a very well-known singer...

question: Who is it, Paul Anka?
answer: He's a rock star, you probably wouldn't know the name. Anyway, I gotta run a couple a dogs up to him...

question: You know, it's T-minus zero and counting, Harry, on this whole shitty deal.
answer: Now Iwo, don't blow this way out of proportion. You think I want to do this. I need the extra cash right now, believe me.

question: If you leave, I'm getting Top Lock to come over and change the front and back doors! I mean it! You get in that van, and I'm taking my building back and putting in a Fingernail Salon!
answer: Come on now, honey, don't say things like that... He puts an arm around her, giving her a perfunctory hug: Let's not make a big issue out of it... Okay? It's really very nice looking, honey.

question: Come on now, honey, don't say things like that... He puts an arm around her, giving her a perfunctory hug: Let's not make a big issue out of it... Okay? It's really very nice looking, honey.
answer: Do you like it?

question: Yeah. I do. Very much. She finishes securing the watch. Thank you.
answer: You're welcome.

question: Yeah it's great and it's something I really needed, so... He leans over and kisses her on the cheek, then picks up his fork and begins poking with disinterest at his food.
answer: Is anything wrong?

question: No. Nothing's wrong. Everything's fine. She resumes eating. Then, desirous of drawing his atten- tion, she fixes her gaze on the table top and smiles pensively, making the assumption that he is looking at her. When no response is forthcoming, she attempts a verbal solicitation:
answer: You're probably wondering why I'm smiling.

question: What?
answer: I was just thinking that I find this moody side of you very attractive.

question: Oh, uh-huh.
answer: In fact, if you want to know, and I can see you're dying to... I completely adore you.

question: Well, same here, honey.
answer: Why are you all wet?

question: You know, there is something I feel I gotta say here, Joan, that's been preying on my mind. Something I maybe should've handled a bit differently with you from the start, about this particular situation I'm in...
answer: What situation?

question: Can you believe this?! Do you see that? Yes it was. * * She looks quickly back to the screen -- a commercial comes on. * What did she say? San Dimas? Where's San Dimas? Let's call the T.V. station and find out.
answer: This is not the way you want to go about this, honey. As she moves OUT OF VIEW into the living room, he turns * to Socorro Tell her, Soco. She shouldn't mess with these people. Will you just once take the benefit of my advice?

question: First you tell me I go around acting too timid...
answer: Yeah, but this is a whole different situation here...

question: And now when I suddenly feel like I could save the Pope in an earthquake, you start trying to...
answer: This is not the Pope we're talking about here, believe me.

question: That's just a figure of speech. They disappear out the front door.
answer: Dammit, Joan, these people are holding all the cards. They'll probably throw you into that bughouse with your sister. You want to go there and call 'em a bunch of names, throw a lot of accusations at them? They don't care. People with that kind of money behind them, with their kind of connections, they never go to jail, you never see them behind bars. Am I getting through to you? Alright. Jesus Christ. This is just nuts, what you're doing.

question: Will you stop trying to undermine me every inch of the way.
answer: Look at this goddamned traffic. *

question: Anyway, I didn't ask you to drag along with me.
answer: You're the one that's dragging along. Go around the goddamned truck. *

question: Don't tell me what to do.
answer: Okay, just let me drive the goddamned car, that's all I ask.

question: Why should I let you drive?
answer: Why? I'll tell you why, because you're a terrible driver, that's why.

question: Oh, now all the ugly little truths are coming out.
answer: You operate this vehicle like it was a cane with a red tip painted on the end of it.

question: Don't talk to me, Harry. I mean it, just don't say another word to me! I was doing just fine until you started in on me...
answer: Driving around with a goddamned ax stuck in your car...

question: And now look at me. I've got purpose tremors...
answer: Is something the fuck bothering you, pal? Can I at least offer some advice?

question: No.
answer: Good. Just barge into the place, honey, and play the big hero. When he tells you your sister's not there, what're you going to do, cry? She stops walking and as he moves up beside her, looks defiantly at him:

question: Okay. What? This isn't going to work. You look like a busboy. They approach a nurses' station and Harry steps forward to address one of TWO NURSES behind the counter:
answer: Excuse me, Nurse...

question: I hope you know what you're doing.
answer: Don't worry. Just do what I told you. They approach room 206.

question: What's the problem, dear?
answer: We're trying to contact Doctor * Park, just to be sure he's authorized you to examine Mrs. Ellerman, because you know, we have to follow certain...

question: I understand. You're doing your job.
answer: Where did your assistant...?

question: And if this little kinglet of corporate shit thinks he can get away with this, he's greatly mistaken. Just wait 'til he hears what I'm going to come out with now.
answer: Put this on.

question: Remember when he passed me off as staff and I was put on official government payroll all through Maui and the Yucatan Mission?
answer: No, I don't. And hurry up, will you. And as Andy steps into the skirt, Joan takes over the uncompleted buttoning chores:

question: I assume you're a fairly recent associate of the doctor's?
answer: That's very correct.

question: Uhm hmmm... What do you specialize in?
answer: I'd say female troubles, mainly.

question: Oh, so Dr. Park feels there's a gynecological involvement here.
answer: Sometimes he does, yes. By the way, did anyone ever tell you what attractive eyebrows you have?

question: Which way? Don't mention it. The Nurse watches briefly as they move away, then extracting a key from her pocket, she steps over to the door and locks it.
answer: And this man, who wouldn't know the truth if it came up and spit him in the eye, is accusing me of lying... She hands him the skirt out through the window: You know what that prick had his lawyer say to me? That I was a pretty, grudge- bearing little malcontent, grasping at some splinter of celebrity for myself at his expense. Can you believe that? She hands him out the blouse and he turns politely away from her semi-nudity as he hands her the doctor's jacket.

question: Here, put this on.
answer: I mean, the arrogance... What did she say your name was?

question: Harry.
answer: Have you got a cigarette, Harry?

question: Stay in the car. Don't talk to anybody, and I'll be right back. Fuck! He turns and moves OUT OF SIGHT.
answer: Christ. A soft WHISTLE comes from the vicinity of the windows behind her, followed by Harry's voice, whispering:

question: Joan? Are you there? Is that you?
answer: Yes, it's me. Hurry up, will you!

question: I'm having a little trouble getting back in.
answer: Oh great, Harry. What have you got me into? Don't worry, honey... You have to get me out of here!

question: Are you alright? ... And in response to Andy's stoical nod: No you're not. What did that bastard do to you?
answer: I need a Kleenex. She moves toward the nightstand with Joan following:

question: You know what they're trying to do, don't you? To force you into signing some kind of agreement that...
answer: Wait, I want to tell you what he said to me... She extracts a tissue from a dispenser on the nightstand: He said I was the only woman he's ever really cared for...

question: What?!
answer: And when he said it... ... he had a tear in his eye...

question: Andy, you don't know what you're saying. You're suffering from hostage syndrome or something.
answer: Well, after all I do love him.

question: You 'love' him?!
answer: Yes, he's been a very important man in my life, you know that.

question: Oh, now he's not a fecal-faced, great white shark!
answer: I don't know where she got that. Will you please keep your voice down. He's very sensitive to what people say.

question: Who's this?
answer: That's the dog trainer.

question: I thought he was working for us.
answer: Well there seems to be a little grey area there, Red.

question: I just want a say, that though you're someone in a category I admire, you've gone to some lengths on this thing here, that I don't entirely agree with...
answer: Sit down. I have a neck condition and it aggravates me to have to look up at you.

question: Okay. No problem. As he seats himself in the other chair, Red reaches up and takes a glass of tea offered by Moncrief: But I want to go on and finish my thought on this, because...
answer: You know, I'm not in the best of health right now, and I've been advised to avoid excitement... Harry takes a second glass from Moncrief: So if you intend to do that... I might just have to have my shock troops blow your brains out.

question: Oh, uh huh.
answer: More sugar.

question: Who is this guy, anyway? Isn't he a little sleazy, Joanie, a bit infra dig? I mean Lewie's a bit of a stiff, but...
answer: You're going to talk to me about sleaze, when you consorted with some maniac tree surgeon, who was flicking his tongue out at me like some rutting iguana, and groping at his naturalia at three in the morning?!

question: Oh, 'him.'
answer: Oh 'him'?! He came at me with an ax!

question: In fact, I've been to the police and I intend to press charges against you...
answer: Honey, he's not supposed to get excited.

question: ... Not only for having my apartment burglarized but for breaking into Andy's house, as well as hiring someone to frighten, harass and intimidate me!
answer: You know, maybe you better not...

question: I'm not here to beg your good opinion...
answer: What is it? Tell him to hold on. First, you assume far more interest in you on my part than exists. I had nothing whatsoever to do with your supposed misfortunes...

question: I don't believe you!
answer: And as regards Andy's house, I'd have no need to break into Andy's house, because I own Andy's house.

question: I don't care whose house you own, you're nothing but a slimy, mean- * minded little hood!
answer: Will you please stop interfering in my personal life, Joanie.

question: Andy, you know something? The kind of woman you are is a danger to the kind of woman I am, so the next time you and your boyfriend have a domestic spat, don't call me!
answer: Well if you're going to take this kind of grumpy attitude, I certainly won't.

question: Jesus Christ! What are you trying to do to me!!
answer: Wait a minute, honey... As she disappears inside, Red re-enters, and covering the speaker vents on the beeper, strides over to Moncrief:

question: You know whose heart this body- snatcher is trying to give me?! A victim of somebody called the Westside Slasher! And this is the doctor you recommended to me! You're killing me, Monroe! You know that?! You're pushing me to the goddamned wall! Joan comes out of the bathroom with the doctor's jacket and moves immediately to the hallway door and exits.
answer: Honey, there's a simple explanation to all of this, if you want me to go into it... I was trying to tell you at dinner... She disappears into an intersecting hallway. Will you just stop for one minute and let me talk to you... It's very complicated...

question: Look, you know, you live a life, honey, you make some mistakes. You get married for maybe mutual benefits, or business considerations weighing on you at the time, and because you don't think the right person is ever going to come along.
answer: I would never have knowingly become involved with a married man.

question: I know that, that's why I was trying to come out and tell you...
answer: Please, I don't want to discuss it anymore. I bet you never read Dante, either.

question: Now there you're 75 percent wrong.
answer: I mean, I can't believe it, that you'd lie to me about this...

question: Okay, I lied. Didn't you ever tell a lie? If not let me kiss your high heel.
answer: I'm going in the house.

question: Wait. Can I call you tomorrow, just to see how you're feeling? Or how things are going?
answer: I have a dress rehearsal tomorrow and a concert on Friday. That's all I care about right now. She reaches to the door handle, then very emotionally: And I don't want to see you anymore.

question: Don't say that, please. I'm asking you to just give me the chance to clear up all these things in my life, because...
answer: No. I didn't extricate myself from the infidelities of one man, just to fall into the arms of the prince of prevaricators...

question: Well, I may be all kinds of a son of a bitch, and the prince of whatever, but that doesn't mean I wouldn't, when it comes down to it, stand up and take the bullet for you. She finally looks over at him, her eyes brimming with tears:
answer: That's not what I observed, Harry.

question: Harry, I want my dog.
answer: Hey, Lee, how are you. I just this minute got back from Vegas. I was dealing a couple of dogs to Paul Anka. I was about to give you a call.

question: Don't embarrass us both, man. Just give me the dog back, and let's preserve the friendship.
answer: Lee, I'm in the neighborhood of getting my hands on the money. I'm about to close a business deal with Vark Zulethian of Zulethian Carpets, you've probably heard of him...

question: Look, our agreement was I could buy the dog back. He's the only thing I got to prove to people what I can do, and all I'm asking you, Lee, is...
answer: Don't make me have to get legal with you, Harry. You sold me the animal, then as a personal favor, I let you borrow him, to demo to some V.I.P.. that probably don't even exist. You haven't been straight with me, man. Just go get the dog. Get in. He ignores the command and looks at Harry:

question: Duke, geh im wagen. Duke jumps into the back of the van. Inside is a large wire travel kennel with another German shepherd inside. Lee removes the leash from Duke and gestures at the other dog:
answer: Why don't you take this dog, Harry. He's green, but maybe you could do something with him. He opens the cage and clips the leash to the dog's collar.

question: No, I don't want the dog.
answer: Go ahead, man. Take him. If you don't want him, pick up some change. Sell him for a pet.

question: Do me one favor, will you? Say 'owner' if you want to, but don't say 'trainer.' I trained that dog.
answer: Let me think about that, okay? He moves past him and OUT OF FRAME.

question: I hate living here now. * I'd like to move to a small town, where it's friendly, and everybody knows each other, and there are no bars on the windows...
answer: And the milkman's a child molester.

question: Thanks, Eddy.
answer: Well, it's true. It doesn't matter where you live. Shit happens.

question: Are you in a bad mood or something?
answer: No. I'm not in a bad mood. Not as bad as yours. Remember when we were on tour in Japan, in '86? The night after we did a concert in Osaka?

question: Could you be more specific?
answer: We had a few drinks in your room. * And a certain intimacy took place. She appears uncertain that she shares the same memory. * And when I asked to see you the next * night, you know what you said? You * were too tired and sleepy.

question: That was witty of me.
answer: But you weren't. Because an hour later, you went into Lewie's room and you didn't come out.

question: Well, if you remember, I was in love with Lewis around that time, which I confided to you, so you did know...
answer: That's not the reason.

question: Excuse me, Eddy, you just passed the turn off to my street. No response. Eddy.
answer: I just want to drive a little, so * we can talk.

question: Anyway, if I remember correctly, * we only kissed. But if that led you to believe something that hurt you in any way, I apologize. He reaches up to adjust the rearview mirror, inadver- * tently drawing her atttention to his hand. * What happened to your hand? It looks like somebody bit you.
answer: Somebody did.

question: Well, am I supposed to guess, or are you going to... She breaks off, suddenly aware that the teeth marks are her own: Oh, Eddy. Why did you do these things?
answer: Because you deserved it.

question: I didn't deserve it. I've always thought of you and treated you as one of my closest and dearest friends...
answer: I use to think very highly of you, too, but now I don't like what I see. In fact, it's been very disturbing to me, Joan. Very disillusioning. To see that before you've even gotten rid of Lewie, you've started up with some other man.

question: Eddy, I want you to take me home now.
answer: You know, there's so many things about me you have no idea of. You never ask me about my life or what I'm thinking, because you have no interest...

question: Yes I do. You can tell me whatever you want to, but let's go back down to...
answer: Creative things, and dreams, and feelings I have, that Lewie or anyone else in your life, are not capable of... She suddenly reaches frantically to the door handle and tries to get out. He grabs hold of her arm and pulls her back into the seat: See? You're not genuinely interested. You're not at all sincere, Joan.

question: Eddy...
answer: You present yourself like you are, but you're not... Don't you think I know that, better than anybody? He takes her arm and places it around his neck.

question: What are you doing?
answer: I want you to listen to me, and I * want you to kiss me. And this time, like you mean it...

question: Are you crazy?! What are you doing, running around with a guy like this!!
answer: You maniacs!! You liars!! You shits!!

question: What are you yelling at me for?! This son of a bitch is probably the Westside Slasher!
answer: I'm finished wagging my tail and leaving little puddles on the floor...!!

question: Wait a minute, honey...
answer: And smiling on command, because I don't give a damn whether any of you like me or not!!!
